posts.name: Josh Vinod
posts.cooked:
Hi.

I’m an aspiring … (PCB engineer? Electronics engineer? I’ve heard and seen it both ways.)

Anyway, 2024 is my senior year so I’d decided to create something that might be useful for teams who struggle with crimping PWM and made it open source.

BEHOLD: The RIO WAGO ADAPTER (name suggestions needed)! Front IMG_20240329_124704 600×600 136 KB Back IMG_20240329_124704 (1) 600×600 121 KB

IMG_20240329_124704 600×600 136 KB

IMG_20240329_124704 600×600 136 KB

IMG_20240329_124704 (1) 600×600 121 KB

IMG_20240329_124704 (1) 600×600 121 KB

Compatible with the original RoboRio and the RoboRio 2.0. Comes with an 1810/9316 varient and no logo varients. This board features the WAGO 233 - 500 series for connecting bare wire or special ferrules to your Rio’s

DIO ports

PWM ports

Relay ports

Analog Ports

RS-232 port

I2C port

RSL port

I’ve cut out the MXP port for NAVX users, however you may need a header extension. Power, CAN , SPI, and USB are also exposed.

The outside holes can be cut or even snapped off if you choose.

This is currently used on 9316 and 1810* and has been tested over a couple of months.

Making the PCB: Schematic: Sch 1700×1102 108 KB PCB Routing (Red is Top Side Wires, Blue is Bottom SIde Wires, Yellow is Top Side Pieces, Green is Bottom Side Pieces):

Sch 1700×1102 108 KB

Sch 1700×1102 108 KB

The Easyeda files should be public to copy, modify, and improve.

The WAGO connectors will need to be bought from Digikey or any other supplier and the connectors will be soldered on. (I used JLCPCB which doesn’t carry the connectors but LCSC does carry the components, however, there was no PCB footprint for me to use from them.)

EasyEda project view:

In EasyEDA open source hardware lab, open source square pools all kinds of electrical design engineerings together to realize resource sharing easily.

EasyEda downloadable project file: BackupProjects_josh_vinod_personal_0_20240329.zip (221.5 KB)

PCB BOM: BOM_Roborio-WAGO-adapter_2024-03-29.xlsx (10.6 KB)

Digikey BOM: https://www.digikey.com/en/mylists/list/G2QZRNXQB2

*: A couple of weeks ago on 1810, a limit switch wire connector connected to DIO 4 fell into a battery terminal. Consequentially, the DIO 4 trace disappeared. Other DIO ports started randomly shorting a few days ago so the electrical lead thought the PCB at fault and removed it.

After closer analysis, it was revealed some of the PCB’s WAGO solder connections were not soldered correctly. But it does still work. We haven’t fully tested if there was damage to the Rio causing those ports to randomly short. Unfortunately the team has opted to not reinstall the PCB due to GKC being less than a week away. TLDR, do not drop low amperage wires into high amperage wires.

So yea, enjoy

posts.name: JBENJI
posts.cooked: If that were COTs - I would buy one - even for a year like 2024 where we only have 2 PWM connections

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: Here’s a similar COTS board, but with latching connectors instead of wagos.

link_counts.title: JST Connector Boards – Swyft Robotics Shop

posts.name: Gordon Walsh
posts.cooked:
To clarify, that board has JST-XH connectors (and their other connector boards have JST-VH and JST-PH). The XH connector is very similar to the PH connector found on the Spark MAX CAN / PWM input and NEO encoder port. It is polarized and has some detent, but I wouldn’t call it latching , not like some of the Molex SL or JST-SM where you have to apply a separate force to unlock it.

Tangential pet peeve: “JST” alone is not a very clear identifier without identifying the connector series.

posts.name: JBENJI
posts.cooked: Gotcha - still a step in the right direction in my opinion, but the WAGO adapter idea seems better. PWM /DIO (and sometimes RSL ) are my pain points - some of it self induced. Every year it seems we find an out of the way but fairly accessible spot for the Roborio and then after the fact drivers/programmers/whoever want to add a PWM controlled LED strip, or some DIO sensor and getting to and securing those sketchy 3 prong connectors is unenjoyable…

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
JBENJI:

RSL ) are my pain points

The RSL connection is the worst of all for us. It will pop out unless hot glued. The connector doesn’t actually clip… Never has as far as I can recall on any Rio and RSL combo we have tried

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked:
That’s really cool. I do worry that it’d be easy to transpose the wires, or to shift them over by one slot.

I wish there was something similar for Molex SL.

posts.name: Josh Vinod
posts.cooked: I just realized I forgot to include the RSL is also connected via Wago terminal. Its next to the relay ports.

posts.name: Josh Vinod
posts.cooked: I believe thay was one gripe my team had about my board. We started to color code the dio and pwm with marking pos, neg, and sig colors to the handles of the wagos with a sharpie.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: JST XA or PA would latch, but the XH used on this board is basically just sized-up PH. I think Swtft has some other JST breakouts in other families that won’t latch either.i

posts.name: Arjun Bhatia
posts.cooked:
We have something like this but for Molex Nano-Fit. I will try to get some photos of it on our robot next comp. image 1310×1280 107 KB

image 1310×1280 107 KB

image 1310×1280 107 KB

You might want to apply for an Altium sponsorship and try designing your own. We went with JLCPCB for the boards (usually 5 day turnaround for plain, 1.6mm, 2-layer, green boards) and DigiKey for components (~2 day turnaround in North America).

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: KiCAD has a plugin to auto generate JLC PCB fab and assembly files, so I recommend it for breakouts in FRC . Altiums takes way too much setup but its better for complex projects.

posts.name: Santiago Quintana Moreno
posts.cooked: Hey! I would love to implement this breakout board in our team. This season we had a lot of problems with DIO and PWM ports in our RoboRio, and we wanted to explore a solution like this. Are you willing to share the files to manufacture it ourselves, or are you somehow able to sell the board itself?
